items.content_html:
I played a gig last night and while it was great, I found it pretty frustrating that playing quietly meant I was barely heard and playing loudly meant I was blasting away the audience to the point they turned me down which made the quiet parts even quieter.

It is frustrating because I prepared a set that was very focused on dynamics, I deliberately tried to make it interesting dynamically, and unfortunately that requires a lot more co-ordination with the venue than I had realised.

At home, rehearsing, this isn't a problem because I run everything through a compressor and a limiter. So the quiet parts and the loud parts are largely the same volume. I have a pretty aggressively tuned compressor and limiter on each input and a more subtle one on the master. I've found this solves for the squashed sound because I can dial in the compressor for each input to exactly where it needs to be for my songs.

After the set I was speaking to the sound guy and he said, that's great, bring your laptop and run your mix through that and then we'll run that into the desk, its better for us if you have everything pre-mixed for the specific artist.

This kind of surprised me, I thought for a singer/songwriter to bring their own interface and laptop and control the dynamics before it reaches the desk would feel a bit like sucking eggs. I think I'm not bold enough to make the assumption that all venues would be into that, but maybe its normal and I'm just out of the loop?

Anyway, I don't think I'll play another show in the mountains as a solo act for a good six months aside from open mics. And next time I'll ask the venue ahead of time if I can bring my own set up, or if their desk has a compressor already built-in etc. I guess its just stuff you learn to ask as you go along. I never had to worry about this stuff when I was in a band, our bassist was the one with audio engineering expertise and we just focused on playing.

I also think I'm done playing venues that are restaurants / cafe's. It is super awkward feeling like you are interrupting their dinner conversation. It's different if you are playing songs they already know but for originals its not compatible I don't think.

items.content_html:
They just changed from a Mexican restaurant to a pizza bar which makes me that much more excited. If there's one thing in this world I love more than music it is cheese.

This is my first "real" gig in many years and it is a big one - two 45 min acoustic sets all 100% originals. I've prepared set lists (which I rarely do) and I've tried to make it a bit of a journey in emotion, dynamics and duration's. I'm even trying a few songs I've never played live before. So a few risks in there to keep it interesting.

I'm not really promoting it as it is a booked thing and I don't think there's much vacancy on a Saturday night at the best of times. But just in case anyone in the area happens upon this post and is interested here are the details:

  • 13th of Jan @ 7:30pm
  • Free entry, but booking ahead is recommended
  • 35 Govetts Leap Rd, Blackheath NSW 2785

Started recording another old song, Lone Wolf. Recorded it all in about 4 hours. Things are pretty busy with Christmas and some sad family happenings so I think mixing will have to wait a while.

items.content_html:
I've been thinking / researching approaches to create a guitar recording set up where I don't over invest in plugins to create sounds I can't recreate in rehearsal or live.

For a while I was thinking, it doesn't matter, I could just bring my laptop to shows and rig up a midi foot pedal to switch different sounds.

But it feels complicated. I also really abhor the licensing model of a lot of VSTs. I hate having millions of things sitting in the system tray bugging me about system updates and having to reinstall and juggle license activations across different machines.

I also don't want other guitarists I play with to have to learn / master my very specific DAW / midi tricks if they want to jam or record using my gear.

And what happens if a VST I use ends up bugging out on some new chip architecture and is no longer supported, if I write a song that relies on that sound, I can't really play that song anymore. Not ideal.

And finally, having the guitar modelling external to the recording software means the machine running the DAW is doing less work, less CPU cycles which I really like the sound of.

So I think I'm largely sold on the idea of having the guitar tone/modelling external to the recording software.

But on the flip side, I don't want to give up on the power of software, I think it is kind of ridiculous that you can spend <$200 for a single piece of software with virtually limitless effects, but people still spend ~$200 on a single pedal that can only do one thing. Seems crazy to me. Maybe that is just because I am a programmer.

In my research I came across the Spark GO.

https://www.positivegrid.com/products/spark-go

It is this tiny little practice amp, but what makes it a good solution potentially for my problem is that it has thousands of pedals / cabinets / tones etc accessible via its software. And you can skip the small tinny speaker and plug it straight into your DAW or into your audio interface. Equally you can plug it into a PA or into the mixer at a gig and have exactly the same sound live. You can switch your presets via the amp itself, the software on the phone, or more preferably via a foot switch (sold separately).

It goes for about $200 in Australia, plus a 4 button pedal board, all in would be about $400 to hopefully solve this problem.

I have never tried it, and I'd really like to. There's also a bunch of other amps out there with in-app modelling. And there are larger variants, so you can skip going into the PA and mic the amp like normal when you play live.

Prior to all this I was getting pretty excited by the thought of loading impluse responses and not using any complicated modelling. I tried it out, but it is fiddly and clunky, at least for me. I find I'm spending a long time trying out different IR files, instead of having a system that emulates the amp that I can just tweak directly. I might use IR's for other things, but for guitar amps, I feel like it was a bit of waste of time for me.

So that's my current thinking, we'll see what happens. Next time I'm down in the city I might walk into a music shop and try some gear out and see if it holds up.

items.content_html:
I've been sick the past two weeks. Nothing too bad, just a cold. But as a result I haven't been doing any shows or recording.

Today though I'm back! I'm recording a very old song of mine called Tea and Scones. I honestly don't remember what it was about at the time. But reading it now, I take the lyrics to be about prioritizing civility over action.

Tea and scones
Leave me alone

But also a little teenage post break up angst

Happy school girl
Don't you laugh at me parading
You love the funny man
But you really love to hate him
I feel dead and I am drowning in success
Going green inside with my jealous lips and jealous eyes

It feels a little Nirvana and a little bit country.

Some of the lyrics need some workshopping.. anyway we'll see how it goes. It's just nice to be out of bed!

Update: Mixing thoughts / struggles

I pretty indulgently spent almost all of today mixing this song instead of doing my real job. I have this theory though that if my brain is really focused on some productive thing, I may as well just take advantage of that instead of being unproductive on the "right" task. Hopefully then my brain gets obsessed with the thing I'm meant to be doing instead once the stack has been cleared.

This was the first time I really tried to pay serious attention to LUFS / volume normalization. My main take away from this session has been, having distinct tracks for different dynamics is helpful, but far more helpful is put your compression / limiters / gates on those groups instead of trying to do it globally.

I wasted a lot of time trying to save time. I thought I could put a lot of compressors and gates on the entire group of vocals, or the entire group of guitar tracks, but it just lead to a loss of clarity.

I'm also starting to really appreciate / understand why all the music production nerds in my life spend so long trying to get levels / dynamics correct before you even start recording. As I was mixing this I kept thinking, if I just was further back from the mic, I wouldn't need to remove this bass. Or if I didn't use a plectrum here, there'd be a lot less artifacts in the guitar mix.

I think over time you just build an intuition on how to save yourself time and I don't have that yet, or not enough.

Monitors? Wonderboom

Before showing my girlfriend my first mix, I spent a good 2 hours with headphones getting all the levels right. Then I played it on her little bluetooth speaker and the vocals were so loud. I still can't believe the difference in dynamics between headphones and speakers. It always surprises me.

So this mix, I only used the wonderboom. I'll go back after this pass and listen on various things, but as a baseline I wanted to use this thing because it has such variation in dynamics and its a pretty common / popular bluetooth speaker that is probably similar to a lot of other speaker people use.

After this mix, I'll not play too much with levels but instead focus on qualitative things like fades, or de-essing, or eq and listen in the car and with headphones.

Not too interesting or surprising but I thought I'd mention it.

items.content_html:
Just finished it this morning. It was an interesting read. I thought to give it a go after hearing about Ben Burgis's book on Hitchens. I wanted to hear from the man himself, on himself, before getting someone else's perspective.

I used to watch Hitchen's clips when I briefly fell down the New Athiesm FACTS AND LOGIC youtube hole. This was well before I considered myself on the left or knew of Hitchen's prior work. Videos would be titled something like "Hitchens DESTROYS Catholic Bishop!!!!".

I didn't know that Hitchen's was an important marxist / socialist activist. I didn't know of his criticisms of the US' war in Vietnam, or his foreign correspondence in war zones or his excursions into South America. I didn't know of his connections to many other important leftist figures.

And after learning of all that, I had it on my to-do list to get up to speed on his work and his eventual drift to the right and support of the war in Iraq.

Having just put it down this morning, I might think of more to say later, but my overall impression was that he didn't drift to the right so much as differed from the left on some key issues. His drift to the right is a false dichotomy, and so often the left disowns people so easily.

In his writing you can see the great respect he has for so many important writers and thinkers. But you can also see hurt and frustration at the way friendships dissolved so casually over differences of opinions. I guess the trouble is, on the left, a difference of opinion is often about quite difficult topics that make it hard to continue having a friendship.

As an example: if you are an anti-imperialist, as most on the left are, then you will have a deep skepticism that any intervention by the U.S could be benevolent or at least not for their own benefit. If you are instead looking at genuine suffering on the ground from corrupt dictators, despots or failed states that have drifted into a violent anarchism you may grow angry with "comrade"'s who would rather see people suffer than have the U.S. offer assistance.

This skepticism is informed by history. It isn't paranoia. But neither is it always logical to just say "America Bad". And for Hitchens, someone who had a deep love for America, and someone so often embedded in countries without democracy, it would have been jarring to register this automatic skepticism in his colleagues.

I can empathize with Hitchen's will to consistently follow his own internal logic, to change his opinions as he encountered new data, or at least anecdata. I don't agree with him but I can easily imagine my own view changing if I so often saw the human suffering that he witnessed first hand.

I also think it is human nature in any group to not admit to certain truths publicly as we are well aware how said truths will be misinterpreted, misconstrued by an opposing group. And Hitchen's just wasn't willing to abide by that code. Maybe the best example of this in the book is the chapter on Salman Rushdie.

So despite not agreeing with his views, I completely understand how his views changed and I think the left needs to be accommodating of transparent internal radical disagreement. We need empathy for other perspectives even if those views can be exploited by neocons and the far right for their own means. It is essential.

Would I recommend the book? Probably not. A lot of it is name dropping and a defense of character that isn't that interesting unless if you already held a strong view. Too much time has passed, and the writing often relies on these topics being current. You do learn a lot of obtuse words for simple terms. Here's some I had to look up while reading Hitch 22:

  • mendacious
  • sardonic
  • mitteleuropa
  • sapphic
  • apotropaica
  • bailiwich
  • desultory
  • embarras de choix
  • filial
  • gelid
  • laconic
  • manumitted
  • pulchritudinous
  • self-abnegation

You could very easily play a dictionary drinking game reading Hitchens, and so often you find the meaning of a word is so simple that the injection feels self indulgent. E.g. pulchritudinous? It means beautiful.

There is a lot of needless french phases thrown in, endlessly. You get the feeling he just really wants the reader to love him, to be impressed. He wants to be remembered.

I can't fault him for that, but it doesn't make for great reading.

And that isn't to say I don't like to expand my vocabulary. At a certain point though it feels like a dare.

The most valuable take away for me was how imperfect political labeling can be, especially when we internally assign them to ourselves. We should have a clarified view of our own moral philosophy, and we should seek to find common ground with their own. When we feel the impulse to change our view, we should do so. Allegiance to a side / a group etc is completely pointless. The groups and sides should be goal oriented, and if those goals do not align with your own moral code anymore, then you need to form a new group. Even if you will be seen as a traitor by your former friends.

The left has arguably never been weaker, and maybe that is because it is "the left" and not a coalition to solve a particular problem with whoever will stand with us.

Played another set at the local open mic. Was so busy this time, I didn't get to go on until around 10pm, but the audience was amazing and I think it went a bit better than last time.

Here's the set for posterity:

  • New Place
  • Listen
  • 23

Also, tried out a new bassist for Baby X last weekend and it went very well. We'll see how it goes.

After the jam, Drew came back to my house to see the recording setup I've been working on, and we just sat down and recorded 3 songs. I uploaded Noth above.

items.content_html:
This time it was at The Family Hotel in Katoomba. Completely different vibe to Zoe's bar which I played a few months ago. I walked in and there were all these muso's and they immediately introduced themselves and welcomed me and showed me the ropes.

A lot of Dylan fans, very interesting people who clearly care a lot about music.

It was honestly so refreshing. I used to gig quite often years ago in Sydney with Baby X. And it was depressing how much of the scene was people trying to be cool, there wasn't a lot of passion for music itself, or bringing something new or earnest/honest.

I think I'll keep it up as a weekly thing when I can.

My guitar was so out of tune, I think because it was in the sun in the car. And I just had to play through it. I also really regretted not bringing my strap, it would have been nice to stand up.

I played Golden, Black Hand and Mirrorman

There was a guy reading poetry, he reminded me a little of Floki from Vikings. His delivery was incredible and he was undeterred from two very rough guys yelling at him for not playing music at an Open Mic night, they were heckling him constantly and he just stayed in character.

You have to ask yourself, why? It could easily have gotten violent, the audience was clearly challenged by the material and weren't super enthused with it. But he was good, and he knew it, and he was challenging all of us just by being there, exactly there.

In other news, Drew my drummer and I are jamming tomorrow with a potential replacement bassist. We have a backyard gig lined up (which I'll talk about later when its more solid).

I recently figured out how to set up the Midi from the Roland Kit while still using the Evo as the sound device. I need to find some good Guitar amp VST's and tweak the drums a bit, but soon I can imagine actually doing a rehearsal at home straight into the DAW, record the whole thing multi track - what a dream.

I bought a long Midi USB cable before I moved house, but I couldn't find it. So I rotated the kit in such a way that its right next to the computer. I kind of like when things move or change because they have to, not because it was initially planned.

Writing about all this makes me realise I'm actually successfully re-orienting my life towards music. It is so easy to forget how it all adds up bit by bit.

items.content_html:
If we look at reality for more than an instant, if we look at the human beings passing us on the street, it’s not bearable. It’s not bearable to watch while the talents and the abilities of infants and children are crushed and destroyed. These happen to be things that I just can’t think about. And most of the time, the factory workers and domestic workers and cashiers and truck drivers can’t think about them either. Their performances as these characters are consistent and convincing, because they actually believe about themselves just what I believe about them—that what they are now is all that they could ever have been, they could never have been anything other than what they are. Of course, that’s what we all have to believe, so that we can bear our lives and live in peace together. But it’s the peace of death.

Actors understand the infinite vastness hiding inside each human being, the characters not played, the characteristics not revealed. Schoolteachers can see every day that, given the chance, the sullen pupil in the back row can sing, dance, juggle, do mathematics, paint, and think. If the play we’re watching is an illusion, if the baby who now wears the costume of the hustler in fact had the capacity to become a biologist or a doctor, a circus performer or a poet or a scholar of ancient Greek, then the division of labor, as now practiced, is inherently immoral, and we must somehow learn a different way to share out all the work that needs to be done. The costumes are wrong. They have to be discarded. We have to start out naked again and go from there.

--Why I Call Myself a Socialist, Wallace Shawn (originally published in Essays, 2010).

So I recently bought two pieces of gear, a Roland electric drum kit and a larger audio interface. My room is tiny, so this relatively small kit is taking up a lot of space, so I need to think a bit about what I can move around / out to make it less chaotic, but also maybe it is fine.

I've found a few good kit sounds on the built in drum module, my favourite is one that has a tambourine blended in with the floor tom and the snare.

Previously I was thinking I'd send midi to the DAW from the kit and use something like Steven Slate Drums plugin. But the sounds that come straight out of the module as audio are pretty good. I haven't figured out how to send the audio out in multiple channels yet, but if I do I'd probably send both audio and midi and mix either side in to taste.

The interface has a standalone mode, you set all the levels and routing when it is plugged in, and then you can save it's state, unplug the computer and just use it headlessly. I really really like this feature. You could easily take it to a show or a rehearsal and route a whole band into PA's or headphones without needing to also have a laptop with you.

It's cool too because I only have a few pairs of headphones, and I don't want to have to constantly plug/unplug them into whatever instrument I'm using at the time, I can just keep the headphones hooked up to the interface and play any instrument and it will come through into the same mix.

I've also been practicing high hat technique a bit, because I never had high hats before, I just had this flat tabletop electric kit. In particular I'm trying to get this fast single-handed approach where you slam the stick in to the side of the hat, and then pull the stick away and it automatically flips the tip of the stick onto the hat, which creates this effortless double hit. I linked to it before, but here it is again.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qk6p5JE5TsY

I think I need to practice my foot technique too, now I have real pedals I've noticed how tired I get, I think I have my feet too far up the pedal, or I've tuned the tension incorrectly. It's all new to me!

I don't think I'll be adding any of my own drums to any recordings for a long time, at least I won't be releasing those versions. Even just keeping time is hard for me at the moment. But it is cool that I can now practice on something far more like a real kit and build up that technique.

items.content_html:
Exactly why an Aboriginal advisory committee to government was divisive I'll never know. I was proud of Australia when we voted in Labor in every state except Tasmania. I was proud when we voted yes to gay marriage. I'm not judging anyone who voted no, I don't think you're racist. I don't think those sorts of accusations make much sense. But I do think you're wrong. All we needed to do was listen, that was the ask, to listen. And we collectively said no.

History never moved linearly towards justice. Maybe this is the way it has to be. But it is hard not to feel winded when we don't rise to the moment.
